p: This plant is mostly found in snowy areas near the Sea of Jeju Island in Korea, and is considered as a traditional medicinal plant. Its leaves are mostly used for the treatment of stomachache, hemorrhoids and rheumatoid arthritis [ 59, 60]. During SARS-CoV-1 infection, Young Bae Ryu et al. used Torreya nucifera ( T. nucifera) plant leaves for in vitro experiments, and the results showed a potential inhibitory effect [ 48, 61]. Ryu et al. isolated 12 phytochemical compounds from the ethanol extract of the T. nucifera leaves. Only the biflavonoid amentoflavone showed efficacy against SARS-CoV-1 [ 61]. This biflavonoid of T. nucifera has the potential to block the activity of 3CLpro of the coronavirus and can inhibit the viral replication [ 61].
